lines.value: we can define a sound wave as a disturbance which travels through some medium
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound is the term to describe what is heard when sound waves pass through a medium to the ear
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all sounds are made by vibrations of molecules through which the sound travels
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for instance when a drum or a cymbal is struck the object vibrates
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these vibrations make air molecules move
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound waves move away from their source where they came from traveling on the air molecules
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the vibrating air molecules reach our ears the eardrum vibrates too
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the bones of the ear vibrate in the same way that of the object that started the sound wave
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these vibrations let you hear different sounds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even music is vibrations
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: irregular vibrations are noise
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people can can make very complex sounds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: we use them for speech
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound waves are longitudinal waves with two parts compression and rarefaction
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: compression is the part of the sound waves where the molecules of air are pushed compressed together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rarefaction is the part of the waves where the molecules are far away from each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound waves are a sequence of compressions and rarefactions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound waves can travel through solids liquids and gases but it cannot travel through a vacuum a place with nothing in it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is why astronauts can not talk to each other in space they need a radio to hear each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound can travel through water faster than through air and even faster in solids like stone iron and steel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound travels at 335 metres 1100 feet per second in the air
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: pitch is the highness or lowness of sound
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: pitch is how humans hear different frequencies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: frequency is determined by the number of vibrations per second
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the highest key on a piano for instance vibrates 4000 times per second
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it has a frequency of 4000 hertz hz or 4 kilohertz khz
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lower keys have lower frequencies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a note an octave higher than another note has twice the frequency of that note
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the intensity of a sound is how much sound energy goes through a square meter in one second
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound waves with higher amplitude bigger vibration have higher intensity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the intensity of a sound is higher closer to the sound source
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: farther away it's less intense
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the inverse square law shows how sound intensity becomes smaller farther from the source
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: inverse square says that when distance gets multiplied by a number sound intensity gets divided by that number squared the number times itself
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: thus twice the distance means a quarter the intensity
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound intensities can be very different
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they can range from 0.000000000001 which are barely heard to 1 w/m 2 painfully loud
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the decibel scale makes sound intensity numbers easier to work with
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a 0.000000000001 w/m 2 intensity is 0 db decibels
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the decibel number increases by 10 the intensity is ten times as much
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so a 1 w/m 2 intensity is 120 db.loudness is how people sense the intensity of sound
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: loudness depends on sound intensity sound frequency and the person's hearing
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: audible sound has frequencies between 20 hz to 20 khz
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: human beings can hear audible sound
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound waves with frequency above 20 khz are called ultrasound waves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sound waves with frequency below 20 hz are called infrasound waves
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: human beings cannot hear ultrasound waves and infrasound waves but some animals like bats and dolphins use them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: older people have an even smaller hearing range
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: people are best at hearing sounds between 1000 hz and 6000 hz
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when a sound source is moving towards someone the frequency seems to increase
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the same thing happens when someone moves toward the sound source
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: frequency seems to decrease when someone moves away from a sound source
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it also seems to decrease when the sound source moves away from someone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is called the doppler effect
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in chemistry a mixture is a substance that is made up of two or more simpler substance s these substances be chemical elements or compounds
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a mixture can be made of liquids solids or gases
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a mixture is not the same as a compound which is made of two or more atoms connected together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for instance a mixture of the gases hydrogen and nitrogen contains hydrogen and nitrogen not the compound ammonia which is made of hydrogen and nitrogen atoms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a mixture where the different parts can be distinguished easily is called heterogenous one where this is not the case is called homogeneous
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a third form is called colloid
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if one substance in a mixture dissolves in the other it is called a solution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example if sugar is put in water it forms a mixture then dissolves to make a solution
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if it does not dissolve it would be called a suspension
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: solids can be mixtures also
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many kinds of soil and rock are mixtures of different minerals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in short a mixture is made up of two or more elements and or compounds which are not chemically combined

lines.value: the noble gases are a group of elements that are all gases

lines.value: these elements are all in group 18 of the periodic table

lines.value: all of them are monoatomic meaning each molecule is a single atom they almost never react with other elements
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is because they have a full 8 electrons outer electron shell
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are six noble gases when the noble gases are used in cold cathode tubes to produce light each of them has a different colour

lines.value: since radon is radioactive it is usually not used for lighting

lines.value: however it has a half life of 0.89 ms after which it decays to ununhexium element 116

lines.value: this means its use is probably limited

lines.value: unicellular organisms are organisms that have one cell
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are divided into two quite different types from different classification kingdoms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: you can observe the larger unicellular organisms by using a compound microscope
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bacteria just appear as dark dots
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: to gather unicellular organisms for observation one can place a cover slip on the surface of pond water and leave it overnight
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by the next morning numerous unicellular organisms will have grown entire colonies on the bottom of the slip
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they multiply fast colonies can double their size in between 30 minutes and a few hours
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: unicellular organisms can be found everywhere
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the oldest forms of life existed 3.8 billion years ago if not longer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they pursue a variety of strategies for survival photosynthesis cyanobacteria chemotrophy many archaea and heterotrophy amoeba
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some unicellular organisms have flagella little tails they use for locomotion or lobopods extensions of the cellular skeleton cytoskeleton which appear as bloblike arms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the flagella of our unicellular ancestors occurs all the way up into the animals where it makes an appearance as flagellated sperm
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: of all the six eukaryote supergroups four are exclusively composed of unicellular organisms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: unicellular organisms vary in size with the smallest bacteria measuring only a third of a micron 300 nanometers across ranging up to the titanic plasmodial slime molds which can grow to 20 cm 8 in across
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the largest unicellular organisms may have millions of nuclei scattered throughout the cellular envelope
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: to observe some of the smallest unicellular organisms requires an electron microscope while the very largest can be seen with a microscope or anything that enhances images

lines.value: the zimbabwe dollar was a currency for zimbabwe from 1980 to 2009

lines.value: because of hyperinflation or inflation that is out of control the reserve bank of zimbabwe had to print banknotes with higher values to cope with the rising cost of living

lines.value: in january 2009 zimbabwe released a banknote for one hundred trillion dollars or $100000000000000

lines.value: the urethra is a tube that connects the bladder to the outside of the body

lines.value: it allows people and animals to remove urine from the body

lines.value: the urethra is part of the urinary system in mammals

lines.value: in male mammals the urethra is also a part of the reproductive system because males use it as a tube for sperm during sex

lines.value: this means that women have bladder infections more often because their bladders are closer to the outside

lines.value: because the male urethra is longer and is not straight a catheter tube to help urination is more difficult in men

lines.value: bertrand arthur william russell 3rd earl russell om frs 18 may 1872 - 2 february 1970 was one of the world's best known intellectuals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was a philosopher logician and mathematician
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he was born in wales but spent most of his life in england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he worked mostly in the 20th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bertrand russell wrote a lot
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he also tried to make philosophy popular
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he gave his opinion on many topics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he wrote the essay on denoting which has been described as one of the most influential essays in philosophy in the 20th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he wrote on very serious issues as well as everyday things
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: continuing his family's tradition of being involved in politics he was a well known liberal as well as a socialist and anti war activist for most of his long life
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: millions looked up to russell as a prophet of the creative and rational life
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at the same time his stances on many topics were extremely controversial

lines.value: born at the height of britain's economic and political ascendancy he died of influenza nearly a century later when the british empire had all but vanished its power dissipated in two victorious but debilitating world wars
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: russell's voice carried enormous moral authority even into his early 90s

lines.value: russell supported nuclear disarmament a lot but did not support the american war in vietnam even when it was popular

lines.value: a mobile phone also known as a wireless phone cell phone or cellular telephone ) is a small portable radio telephone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the mobile phone can be used to communicate over long distances without wires
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it works by communicating with a nearby base station also called a cell site which connects it to the main phone network
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when moving if the mobile phone gets too far away from the cell it is connected to that cell sends a message to another cell to tell the new cell to take over the call
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is called a hand off and the call continues with the new cell the phone is connected to
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the hand off is done so well and carefully that the user will usually never even know that the call was transferred to another cell
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: as mobile phones became more popular they began to cost less money and more people could afford them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: monthly plans became available for rates as low as us$30 or us$40 a month
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cell phones have become so cheap to own that they have mostly replaced pay phones and phone booths except for urban areas with many people
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the 21st century a new type of mobile phone called smartphones have become popular
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now more people are using smartphones than the old kind of mobile phone which are called feature phones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: mobile phones in the 1950s through 1970s were large and heavy and most were built into cars
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the late 20th century technology improved so people could carry their phones easily
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: although dr martin cooper from motorola made the first call using a mobile phone in 1973 it did not use the type of cellular mobile phone network that we use today
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the first mobile phone networks were created in the late 1970s in japan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: now almost all urban areas and many country areas are covered by mobile phone networks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a cell phone combines technologies mainly telephone radio and computer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most also have a digital camera inside
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cell phones work as two way radios
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they send electromagnetic microwaves from base station to base station
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the waves are sent through antennas
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is called wireless communication
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: early cell telephones used analog networks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they became rare late in the 20th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: modern phones use digital networks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the first digital networks are also known as second generation or 2g technologies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most used digital network is gsm global system for mobile communication
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is used mainly in europe and asia while cdma code-division multiple access networks are mainly used in north america
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the difference is in communication protocol
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other countries like japan have different 2g protocols
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a few 2g networks are still used
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: 3g are more common and many places have 4g.the radio waves that the mobile phone networks use are split into different frequencies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the frequency is measured in hz
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: low frequencies can send the signal farther
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: higher frequencies provide better connections and the voice communications are generally clearer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: four main frequencies are used around the world 850 900 1800 and 1900 mhz
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: europe uses 900 and 1800 mhz and north america uses 850 and 1900 mhz
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: today there are mobile phones that work on two three or four frequencies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most advanced phones work on all frequencies
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are called world phones and can be used everywhere
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are different kinds of phones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a flip phone flips open and is best for calling
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a bar phone is shaped like a candy bar and the keys and screen are on one face
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a slate phone is a phone that has almost no buttons and uses a touchscreen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most smartphones are slates
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a slider phone slides on rails
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it can slide out number keys or a mini keyboard but some do both
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a swivel spins on an axle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when a mobile phone is switched on its radio receiver finds a nearby mobile phone network base station and its transmitter sends a request for service
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: computers in the base station check if the phone is allowed to use the network
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the base station covers an area called a cell
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a phone can move between different cells but will only communicate with one cell at a time
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is why mobile communications are sometimes called cellular communications
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: once connected to a station the mobile phone can make calls
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because the network knows that the phone is connected to that particular cell it can also route calls to the mobile phone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes the radio connection to the cell is lost for example when you go underground
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this means the phone cannot make or receive calls until the connection is made again
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the network is the company that provides the phone service
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in most areas there will be more than one mobile network
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: customers choose networks based on how well the different networks work in their area or by price
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are two main ways to pay for mobile phone calls the others have a special radio inside them that only makes phone calls when the phone is activated
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when someone buys a contract the network gives them a code that if they enter it into the phone the phone will then make calls
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is usually impossible to switch to a different network's code on this type of phone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the majority of these cdma phones are used in the united states and nearby countries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a majority of new mobile phones from the 21st century are smartphones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these phones are basically small computers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: besides calling they can be used for email browsing the internet playing music and games and many other functions that computers can perform
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most smartphones run a common mobile operating system
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this allows developers to make mobile apps that work on many different phones without needing to change the code
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: examples of smartphones include apple's iphone which uses ios software and samsung's galaxy series one of many phones that use the android platform made by google
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: niue is an island country in the south pacific

lines.value: the standard model sm of physics is a theory of the elementary particles which are either fermions or bosons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it also explains three of the four basic forces of nature
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the four fundamental forces are gravity electromagnetism the weak force and the strong force
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gravity is the one the model does not explain
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the model uses the parts of physics called quantum mechanics and special relativity and the ideas of physical field and symmetry breaking
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some of the mathematics of the sm is group theory and also as equations which have biggest and smallest points called lagrangians and hamiltonians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fermions are particles that join together to make up all matter we see
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: examples of groups of fermions are the proton and the neutron
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fermions have properties such as charge and mass which can be seen in everyday life
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they also have other properties such as spin weak charge hypercharge and color charge whose effects do not usually appear in everyday life
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these properties are given numbers called quantum numbers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fermions are particles whose spin numbers equal an odd positive number times one half 1/2 3/2 5/2 etc we say that fermions have half integer spin an important fact about fermions is that they follow a rule called the pauli exclusion principle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this rule says that no two fermions can be in the same place at the same time because no two fermions in an atom can have the same quantum numbers at the same time
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: fermions also obey a theory called fermi dirac statistics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the word fermion honors the physicist enrico fermi
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are 12 different types of fermions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: each type is called a flavor their names are matter is made of atoms and atoms are made of electrons protons and neutrons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: protons and neutrons are made of up and down quarks
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: you can find one lepton by itself but you can never find quarks alone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is because quarks are held together by the color force
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bosons are the second type of elementary particle in the standard model
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all bosons have an integer spin 1 2 3 etc so many of them can be in the same place at the same time
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are two types of bosons gauge bosons and the higgs boson
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gauge bosons are what make the fundamental forces of nature possible
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: we are not yet sure if gravity works through a gauge boson every force that acts on fermions happens because gauge bosons are moving between the fermions carrying the force
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: bosons follow a theory called bose einstein statistics
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the word boson honors the indian physicist satyendra nath bose
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the standard model says that there are
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are four basic known forces of nature
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these forces affect fermions and are carried by bosons traveling between those fermions
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the standard model explains three of these four forces
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the standard model falls short of being a theory of everything
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it does not include the full theory of gravitation as described by general relativity or account for the accelerating expansion of the universe as possibly described by dark energy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the model does not contain any dark matter particle that has all the properties observed in observational cosmology
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the sm is believed to be theoretically self consistent
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it has demonstrated huge and continued successes in experimental predictions but it does leave some things unexplained
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: romantic music is music written in the 19th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this was the period called the romantic period by musicians
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in literature and some other arts the romantic period is often said to begin and finish earlier around mid 18th to mid 19th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the classical period artists liked to see clear forms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: 18th century architecture nearly always shows a lot of symmetry
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the gardens of the palace at versailles are a good example of this with their very tidy patterns of straight paths circular ponds and neatly clipped hedges
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in music the classical composers such as haydn mozart beethoven and schubert liked to compose music which had a clear plan like sonata form

lines.value: in the romantic period artists thought that feeling and passions were more important than formal plans

lines.value: this can be seen in the gardens designed by capability brown e.g in at blenheim palace oxford

lines.value: the gardens are made to blend into nature

lines.value: in music the romantic composers may still use plans like sonata form but feelings and passions are important

lines.value: they often write what is called programme music which means music that describes something or tells a story

lines.value: beethoven's sixth symphony is called the pastoral which means that it is about the countryside

lines.value: although beethoven is usually called a composer of the classical period he is also an early romantic

lines.value: later composers such as felix mendelssohn wrote pieces like hebrides overture which describes the sea coming into fingal's cave in the hebrides islands in scotland

lines.value: other composers who wrote a lot of programme music include franz liszt 1811-1886 and richard strauss 1864-1949

lines.value: strauss always wrote in a late romantic style even although he lived well into the 20th century

lines.value: the romantic period was also the period of nationalism

lines.value: in the 19th century a lot of european countries as we know them were being formed

lines.value: die meistersinger von nurnberg the mastersingers of nuremberg is an opera by richard wagner
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is the only comic opera that wagner wrote
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: wagner wrote the words the libretto in 1862 and composed the music in 1867
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was first performed in munich in 1868
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the story is set in the town of nuremberg german nurnberg in 16th century germany

lines.value: the mastersingers german meistersinger were a guild of singers in germany many centuries ago

lines.value: although hans sachs was a real person the story of the opera was made up by wagner

lines.value: it is a story about a song contest

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it has several tunes which are sometimes cleverly played at the same time counterpoint
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these tunes are used during the opera and are associated with particular people or ideas such tunes are called leitmotifs

lines.value: light is a type of energy

lines.value: light is electromagnetic radiation that shows properties of both waves and particles

lines.value: each wave has a wavelength or frequency

lines.value: the human eye sees each wavelength as a different color

lines.value: rainbows show the entire spectrum of visible light

lines.value: the separate colors moving in from the outer edges are usually listed as red orange yellow green blue indigo and violet

lines.value: other colors can be seen only with special cameras or instruments wavelengths below the frequency of red are called infrared and higher than of violet are called ultraviolet

lines.value: the other main properties of light are intensity polarization phase and orbital angular momentum

lines.value: in physics the term light sometimes refers to electromagnetic radiation of any wavelength whether visible or not

lines.value: this article is about visible light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: read the electromagnetic radiation article for the general concept
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in a vacuum light moves at the speed of light which is 299792458 meters or about 186282 miles per second

lines.value: this means it takes about 8 minutes for light to reach earth from the sun
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in glass it travels at about two thirds as fast
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: light moves in a straight line creating shadows when the path of light is blocked
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: more solid things will have a darker shadow things that are more clear have a lighter shadow and transparent things will have none or very little shadow
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: light can pass through transparent things the most easily

lines.value: when light is not in a vacuum it travels more slowly than its maximum speed of light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the slowest light ever recorded moved at 38 mph
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example a lamp gives off light and everything else in the same room as the lamp reflects its light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: every color of light has a different wavelength

lines.value: the shorter the wavelength the more energy the light has
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the speed at which light moves does not depend on its energy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: going through partly clear objects can slow light down by a very small amount
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: white light is made up of many different colors of light added together
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when white light shines through a prism it splits up into different colors becoming a spectrum
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: red light has the longest wavelength and violet purple light has the shortest

lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: our eyes cannot see those kinds of energy but there are some cameras that can see them

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: light and color are forms of analog information

lines.value: however electronic cameras and computer displays work with digital information
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so electronic cameras or document scanners make a digital version of a color image by separating out the full color image into separate red green and blue images

lines.value: later a digital display uses pixels of just those three colors

lines.value: computer screens use only these three colors in different levels

lines.value: the brain combines them to see all of the other colors in the image

lines.value: stonehenge is a prehistoric world heritage site eight miles 13 kilometers north of salisbury in wiltshire england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is made of a henge with standing stones in circles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were three main building phases each between about 3100 bc and 1950 bc the first circle ~3000 bc was made of timber
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the post holes for the timber have been found
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: around 2600 bc the builders gave up timber in favour of stone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of the construction took place between 2640 and 2480 bc
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the first stone circle was a set of bluestones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the holes held up to 80 standing stones shown blue on the plan only 43 of which can be traced today
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the bluestones made of dolerite an igneous rock are thought to have been brought from the preseli hills away in modern day pembrokeshire wales
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this the long distance human transport theory was bolstered in 2011 by the discovery of a megalithic bluestone quarry at craig rhos y felin near crymych in pembrokeshire
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is the most likely place where some of the stones were got
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another theory is that they were brought much nearer to the site as glacial erratics by the irish sea glacier
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this theory is not preferred because there is no evidence of glacial deposition within southern central england
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: later ~2400 bc 30 huge grey sarsen stones were brought to the site
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they were erected in a circle 33 metres in diameter with lintels on top of the standing stones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the remaining bluestones were placed as an inner circle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the site was in use until the bronze age
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the modern stonehenge consists entirely of original stones some of which have been replaced in upright position
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the stones may have come from a quarry about 25 miles 40 km north of stonehenge on the marlborough downs or they may have been collected from a litter of sarsens on the chalk downs which are closer
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the stones were dressed worked on and given mortice and tenon joints
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: 30 were erected as a 33 metres 108 ft diameter circle of standing stones with a ring of 30 lintel stones resting on top
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the lintels were fitted to one another using another woodworking method the tongue and groove joint
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: each standing stone was about 4.1 metres 13 ft high 2.1 metres 6 ft 11 in wide and weighed about 25 tons
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are also several passage tombs and many tumuli nearby
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: stonehenge however does have a number of satellite structures which are part of the ritual landscape
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: no one knows who built stonehenge or why they built it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during the summer solstice the sunrise lines up with some of the stones in a particular way
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this suggests that the arrangement of stones may work as a calendar
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in egypt and south america similar ancient buildings can be found
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they also show the time of the solstice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: stonehenge itself is owned by the crown and managed by english heritage
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the surrounding land is owned by the national trust
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the world heritage site includes avebury and stonhenge together though they are quite distinct sites
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: *malone caroline
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: neolithic britain and ireland
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tempus stroud gloucestershire
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ireland is a european country on the island of ireland
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is a member of the european union
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the country is sometimes called the republic of ireland in order to distinguish between the territory of the irish state and island proper but ireland is its official name
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it covers about five sixths of the island of ireland
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the other sixth is called northern ireland which is still part of the united kingdom
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the republic's capital is dublin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cork is the second largest city in the country and the third largest on the island of ireland
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the population of ireland is 4.6 million
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: english is the main language spoken
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the irish language is widely taught in all schools and it is still spoken as a first language in some areas of the country known as the gaeltacht
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: irish is the first official language followed by english
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: several hundred years ago the english took over the country and made it part of the united kingdom in 1801
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ireland left the united kingdom in 1922 and has been an independent country since then
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the head of state the president is elected for seven years by the adult citizens
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the same president can only be elected twice 14 years
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: most of the president's tasks are representing and ceremonial ones
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the president has little power over the government
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ireland is a democracy and people vote for their representatives
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the taoiseach equivalent to a prime minister is selected by the parliament
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the taoiseach is usually the head of the biggest party
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the oireachtas equivalent to the parliament consists of the dail eireann the lower house and the seanad the upper house
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the system is similar to that of france or the united states except that the president is not an executive
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the main political parties in ireland are fine gael 25% sinn fein 22% fianna fail 18% the labour party 7% and others ref red c poll 29 th june 2014
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: ireann]] the lower house and the seanad the
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gothic architecture are building designs as first pioneered in western europe in the middle ages
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it began in france in the 12th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the gothic style grew out of romanesque architecture
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it lasted until the 16th century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: by that time the renaissance style of architecture had become popular
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the important features of gothic architecture are the pointed arch the ribbed vault the flying buttress and stained glass windows which are explained below
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gothic architecture is best known as the style of many of the great cathedrals abbeys and churches of europe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is also the architecture of many castles palaces town halls universities and also some houses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many church buildings still remain from this period
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even the smallest gothic churches are often very beautiful while many of the larger churches and cathedrals are thought to be priceless works of art
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many are listed with the united nations educational scientific and cultural organization unesco as world heritage sites
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the 19th century the gothic style became popular again particularly for building churches and universities
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this style is called gothic revival architecture
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gothic architecture was at first called the french style ().
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the word gothic was used later during the renaissance as an insult
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an italian writer named giorgio vasari used the word gothic in the 1530s because he thought buildings from the middle ages were not carefully planned and measured like renaissance buildings or the buildings of ancient rome
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he said that as the barbaric goths had destroyed the classical world so this modern art had destroyed the architecture of the twelfth century
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after vasari many other people used the word gothic to describe architecture with pointed arches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at the end of the 12th century western europe was split into different states which were beginning to become the countries that are known today
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the holy roman empire ruled a big part of europe including the modern countries of germany the netherlands belgium luxembourg switzerland austria eastern france and much of northern italy apart from venice
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: historians believe emperor charlemagne began the holy roman empire in 800 ad.the countries of france and spain were split into kingdoms
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: england was ruled by a king whose family also had a lot of land in france
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: norway was influenced by england while the other scandinavian countries and poland were influenced by germany
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at that time there was a lot of trade between towns and states
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this caused the towns to grow larger
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: germany holland and belgium had many big towns that grew peacefully often trading with each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because of the peace and wealth of these towns they showed their pride by building huge town halls often with very tall towers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in england and france most people did not live in towns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they lived on farms which were often owned by a rich nobleman or lord
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the house of the lord was usually called a manor house
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: italy was mostly split up into small city states which often fought each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cities often had high walls and many of the houses built at this time were tall high towers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in western europe in the middle ages almost everyone belonged to the roman catholic church
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the roman catholic church has one head the pope
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: during the middle ages one language was used in churches all across europe church latin which had developed from ancient latin
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the churches of each area had a local bishop who came under the pope
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: . each bishop had a throne where he could sit when priests and people came to him
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a church which has a bishop's throne is called a cathedral
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cathedrals were usually the biggest and most beautiful churches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the early middle ages many monasteries were built all over europe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a group of holy men lived and worked and prayed there
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: monks belonged to different orders which had different rules
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the biggest number of monasteries were homes to the monks of the benedictine order
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: their monasteries were generally in towns and they often built very big churches called abbeys for the monks and the townspeople to worship in
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other orders of monks like the cistercians did not live near towns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: nowadays their abbeys are seen as beautiful ruins in the english countryside
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in france there were also benedictines as well as cluniac orders
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the great monastery at cluny built in the romanesque style was the biggest in europe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the abbey and other buildings were very well planned so for hundreds of years other monasteries were influenced by that plan
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the 13th century st francis of assisi started the franciscans who were often called the grey friars because of their grey brown robes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the dominicans were founded by st dominic in toulouse and bologna
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the dominicans built many of italy's gothic churches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: abbot suger was the head of a large monastery just north of paris in france
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the monastery had a large church the abbey of saint denis and also a royal palace where the french kings sometimes stayed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: abbot suger was a close friend to two kings louis vi and louis vii
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in 1127 suger had the idea to rebuild the great abbey church of saint denis
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he began by changing the west front or facade which was about 200 years old and had only one small door
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: suger's grand design had three big doors like the arches on the arch of constantine in rome which were to let in all the crowds on special holy days
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the facade also had a big round window in the centre called a rose window which was the first one in france
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: abbot suger did not then rebuild the part of the church inside the west doors the nave where most of the ordinary people stood
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the next part that he rebuilt was the eastern end
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: abbot suger wanted this part to make people think of heaven
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he wanted it to be very light and bright with great big windows of beautifully coloured glass
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: to do this he looked at all the most modern designs and all the clever things that other architects had done
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: he put all the new ideas together in one building
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was the first building of the new gothic style
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but of course it was not called gothic at this time
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was called the french style the new east end was dedicated or given to god on june 11 1144
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: other architects soon copied the design for other big churches and cathedrals in northern france
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: after abbot suger's death the rest of the church was also rebuilt in the new style and got two more much larger and more decorated rose windows one on either side
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the style soon spread to england and through france the low countries germany spain and northern of italy and sicily
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: note the architectural vocabulary words are written in bold type and are explained and or shown on the plan and cross section
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: romanesque was the style of architecture in europe before the gothic style
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gothic architecture grew out of romanesque architecture
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there was not a clean break between the two styles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many of the features of gothic architecture did not begin in the gothic period
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they were already there in romanesque architecture and slowly changed to become gothic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the main changes were the pointed arch and the flying buttress
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these two developments allowed many other changes to happen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: romanesque buildings had thick walls small windows round arches and flat buttresses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gothic buildings had thinner walls larger windows pointed arches and large buttresses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: all the types of buildings and the general shape of the buildings were already there in the romanesque period
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the types of buildings were the cathedral church the parish church the monastery the castle the palace the great hall and the gatehouse
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: before the 20th century the landmark building in almost every town was a church cathedral abbey or town hall with its tall tower or spire rising high above all the houses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many of these buildings were from the middle ages and were romanesque or gothic in style
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the groundplan of most gothic churches is shaped like a cross
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the long nave makes the body of the church and crossing it the arms are called the transept
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the other side of the transept is the chancel which is often called the choir because that is where the priest and the choir sing the services
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the nave usually has a passageway or aisle on either side
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes there are two aisles on each side
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the nave is usually a lot taller than the aisles and has high windows which light up the central space
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the upper part of the building where these windows are is called the clerestory or clear storey
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is pronounced clair rest tree some gothic churches in germany and austria and also milan cathedral which was built in the german style often have nave and aisles of almost the same height and are called hallenkirke hall church
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the cathedral of st stephen of vienna is an example
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in some churches with double aisles like notre dame paris the transept does not stick out beyond the aisles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in english cathedrals the transepts always stick out a long way and sometimes there are two transepts as at salisbury cathedral
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is at the eastern end that gothic churches are the most different from each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in england the eastern end it is usually long and often has two parts
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is usually square or has a lady chapel a place to pray to the virgin mary
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in france the eastern end is often polygonal and has by a passage for walking called an ambulatory
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: often french churches have a ring of chapels called a chevette
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: german churches are often like those of france at the eastern end
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in italy there is no long chancel jutting out beyond the transept
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there is usually just a semicircular chapel as at florence cathedral
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: image:cath saint julien.jpg|the east end of le mans cathedral shows a ring of chapels or chevette the clerestory windows and flying buttresses
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the transept has towers on it.image:york-minster-inside.jpg|the interior inside of york minster shows clustered columns vaulted roof traceried window ancient stained glass and a stone screen
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: image:koelner dom nordseite des chors.jpg|the interior of cologne cathedral shows three stages the arcade at the lowest level the gallery in the middle and the clerestory windows
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the facade or west front of a large church or cathedral is designed to make a big impression on the worshippers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one of the best known is notre dame de paris
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the centre of the facade is the main door or portal often with two side doors as well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the arch of the middle door is often an important piece of sculpture usually christ in majesty
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes there is a stone post in the middle of the doorway where there is a statue of the madonna and child
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are many other carved figures in niches set all around the portals
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes there are hundreds of stone figures carved all across the front of the building
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: above the middle door there is a large window which is usually a rose window like that at reims cathedral but not in england scotland belgium or scandinavia where there will nearly always be a very large pointed window to let in lots of light
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in italy the facade is often decorated with coloured marble and mosaic made of little coloured tiles and not so many statues as at orvieto cathedral the facade of a french cathedral and many english spanish and german cathedrals usually has two towers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: large gothic churches and cathedrals are often very tall
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the inside the nave is usually at least twice as high as it is wide which gives the church a very tall narrow look
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some of the churches in france and germany have naves that are three times as high as they are wide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: cologne cathedral is an example
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the tallest nave is at beauvais cathedral which is 157.5 feet high
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: westminster abbey is 102 feet high
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the outside most gothic churches both big and small have at least one tower
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in italy there are domes on the churches and the tower stands to one side
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but in most other countries cathedrals generally have two towers and quite often have three
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some have even more
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: laon cathedral was planned to have seven but they were not all built
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes there is just one tower with a huge spire as at salisbury
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: lincoln cathedral had the tallest spire of the middle ages at 527 feet 160 metres
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because a pointed arch points upwards it makes people look upwards
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in gothic architecture the whole building is designed to make people look up
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are long narrow columns long narrow windows and high pointed roofs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the inside the arches of the roof rise up like branches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the outside there are often lots of fancy bits along the edge of the roof and on the tops of buttresses and above the windows
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these are called pinnacles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: milan cathedral has hundreds of them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gothic architecture usually has a lot of windows
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sainte chapelle is a famous example
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at gloucester cathedral in england the east window is as big as a tennis court
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: milan cathedral also has windows of about the same size
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the flying buttresses which arch across the roof of the aisle were used to support the roof above the windows so the walls did not have to be so thick
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the columns of the inside the ribs of the vault or roof and the flying buttresses made a strong stone skeleton
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in between these parts the walls and the filling of the vaults could be of lighter thinner material
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: between the narrow buttresses the walls could be opened up into large windows
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: through the gothic period because of the pointed arch gothic windows were able to change from simple openings to very rich designs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the windows were very often filled with stained glass which made coloured light in the building and was used for story telling pictures
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: pointed arches were used in persian architecture and from 641 ad onwards they were a feature of islamic architecture
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: knowledge of the pointed arch spread into europe through the crusaders who travelled to the middle east from 1096 onwards
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: also islamic forces had taken over parts of spain where they built cities and mosques with pointed arches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: architectural historians think that the pointed arch was also used by some european architects because it was a very strong way of making an arch
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in gothic architecture the pointed arch is used in every place where an arch is needed both for strength and for decoration
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: gothic openings such as doorways windows arcades and galleries have pointed arches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a row of arches is called an arcade
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a row of arches that is up high on a building is a gallery
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: rows of pointed arches were used to decorate walls
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is known as blind arcading
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: often walls were made with tall narrow arched openings in them that could be used to stand statues in
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an opening like this is called a niche which is pronounced neesh
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an arched roof built of bricks or stone is called a vault
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the romanesque period before the gothic some churches had vaulted roofs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they were always based on perfectly semi circular shapes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there were two main ways to make a nave vault in the romanesque period
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a vault could be long like a tunnel
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: churches with this type of vault were always rather dark
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: or it could be square like two tunnels crossing each other
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this meant that the columns that carried the vault always had to be placed on a perfectly square ground plan which was not always possible
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: one of the good things about pointed arches was that they could be narrow and tall or flattened and wide
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: using pointed arches architects could make vaults of very different shapes
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they did not even have to be rectangular
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a gothic architect could make a vault with one side narrow two sides wide and the last side even wider
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they could make a vault with three sides or five sides quite easily by using pointed arches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the vaults were made of ribs which met each other at the highest part of the vault
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in between the ribs were sloping surfaces of stone or brick that could be much thinner and lighter than the ribs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at first the pattern made by the ribs was quite plain like romanesque vaults but architects particularly in england soon started adding small ribs in between the main ones and making different patterns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some vaults like this can also be seen in spain and germany but not usually in france or italy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in the gothic period the shape and style of pointed arches changed
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but the changes were not the same in every country
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: with pointed arches windows could be made very large
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: architects made many designs of pointed arches crossing each other in different ways
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these designs were often used in windows which look as if they are filled with beautiful stone lace
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is called tracery
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the stone tracery was used to hold the glass in place
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: an architectural historian can often tell just how old a part of a building is by looking at the window tracery design
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the simplest gothic arch is a long opening with a pointed arch known in england as the lancet
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a lancet is a sharp knife so these windows are knife shaped
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: very often lancet windows are put together in a group of three or five
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: salisbury cathedral is famous for the beauty of its lancet gothic architecture
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in england the style is called early english gothic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: york cathedral in england has a group of five lancet windows that are 50 feet high and are still full of ancient glass
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are called the five sisters
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these simple windows are also found at chartres cathedral and laon cathedral in france
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are the most usual sort of gothic windows in italy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many gothic openings have tops that are based upon an equilateral triangle
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the equilateral arch has a very pleasing look and gives a wide opening useful for doorways arcades and big windows
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: these arches are often filled with tracery in circular designs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in england this style is called geometric decorated gothic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it can be seen at many english and french cathedrals for example lincoln cathedral in england and notre dame in paris
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some gothic windows have designs in the tracery or even in the top of the window itself that rises up like a flame
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is called flamboyant gothic
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: tracery like this makes a very rich and lively effect
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some of the most beautiful and famous windows of europe have this type of tracery
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it can be seen at st stephen's vienna sainte chapelle in paris at the cathedrals of limoges and rouen in france and at milan cathedral in italy
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in england the most famous windows like this are the west window of york minster with its design based on the sacred heart the east window at carlisle cathedral and the east window of selby abbey
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: architectural historians sometimes argue about which of these is the most beautiful
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: flame shaped arches are not as strong as ordinary pointed arches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it is never used for making a vaulted roof
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if this shape is used to make a doorway there is generally another stronger arch around it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: another way is to make a square topped door that has flamboyant decoration over the top
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in france there are many doorways both in churches and in houses that are like this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they are rare in england but there is one at rochester cathedral
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in england the flamboyant style was used wall arcading and niches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the most famous examples in are in the lady chapel at ely the screen at lincoln and the facade of exeter cathedral
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in german and spanish gothic architecture the flamboyant style is often used for opnwork stone screens
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the famous pulpit in vienna cathedral is made like this
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the depressed arch is wide and looks as if it has been pushed almost flat
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when arches like this are used to make great big windows they need to be supported by many tall thin vertical shafts and horizontal transoms so that the window looks as if it has been divided up into a grid lots of rectangles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this sort of decoration is used on walls as well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in england the style is called perpendicular gothic style
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: at gloucester cathedral the perpendicular east window is said to be as large as a tennis court
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are three very famous large chapels in this style king's college chapel cambridge st george's chapel at windsor castle henry vii's chapel at westminster abbey
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the other famous example is bath abbey
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: a gothic cathedral was designed to be like a model of the universe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: everything about the building was designed to tell a message about god
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the statues the decoration stained glass windows and wall paintings told bible stories such as how god created the world and how he rules over everything that is in the universe the seasons of the year and the stars in the sky
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: carvings near the door often show the signs of the zodiac because the patterns of stars in the sky were very important to farming people who did not have calendars to tell them when to plant and when to harvest
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: above the main door is often a sculpture of jesus on a throne judging the people of the earth
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many pictures and sculptures are there to remind people to live good lives because they never know what will happen next
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many churches were very richly decorated both inside and out
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the statues were often painted in bright colours but nowadays only tiny bits remain at chartres cathedral and some other places
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: wooden ceilings were usually brightly coloured
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes the stone columns were painted as well
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: even though some things about gothic architecture stay the same other things look different in different countries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: different building materials were found in different parts of europe
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this is one of the differences in the architecture between different places
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in france there was limestone
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was good for building because it was soft to cut but got much harder when the air and rain got on it
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it was usually a pale grey colour
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: france also had beautiful white limestone from caen which was perfect for making very fine carvings
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: england had coarse limestone red sandstone and dark green purbeck marble which was often used for architectural decorations like thin columns
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in northern germany netherlands denmark baltic countries and northern poland there was no good building stone but there was clay for making bricks and tiles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: so many of these countries have brick gothic churches and even brick gothic castles
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in italy limestone was used for city walls and castles but brick was used for other buildings
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: because italy had lots of beautiful marble in many different colours many buildings have fronts or facades decorated in coloured marble
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: some churches have very rough brick facades because the marble was never put on
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: florence cathedral for example did not get its marble facade until the 1800s
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: in some parts of europe there were many tall straight trees that were good for making very large roofs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: but in england by the 1400s the long straight trees were running out
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: many of the trees were used for building ships
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the architects had to think of a new way to make a wide roof from short pieces of timber
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: that is how they invented the hammer beam roofs which are one of the beautiful features seen in many old english churches
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: french cathedrals and those in germany and belgium are often very high both inside and outside
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the transepts do not stick out far
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the facades in france nearly always have three doors a rose window and two towers
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are often facades with doors on the transepts as well as the front
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the thing that makes english cathedrals different from the others is that they are long and look horizontal like big ocean liners
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: english cathedrals nearly all took hundreds of years to build and every part is in a style that is quite different to the next part
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: only salisbury cathedral was not built in lots of styles the west window is very large and is never a rose window
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the west front may have two towers like a french cathedral or none
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there is nearly always a tower at the middle of the building which may have a big spire
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: sometimes they are so big that it was impossible to finish them until modern times
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the spires are quite different to english spires because they are made of lacy openwork

lines.value: there are also many hallenkirke or hall churches which have no clerestorey windows
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the nave and the aisles are about the same height
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: spanish cathedrals often have chapels all around them
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the roof often has many different types of towers and spires
lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: on the outside the facade is often decorated with marble

lines.value: the columns and arches are often decorated with bright coloured paint
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there are also mosaics with gold backgrounds and beautifully tiled floors is geometric patterns

lines.value: inflation means that the general level of prices is going up the opposite of deflation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: more money will need to be paid for goods like a loaf of bread and services like getting a haircut at the hairdresser's
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: economists measure inflation regularly to know an economy's state
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: inflation changes the ratio of money towards goods or services more money is needed to get the same amount of a good or service or the same amount of money will get a lower amount of a good or service
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: economists defined certain customer baskets to be able to measure inflation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: there can be positive and negative effects of inflation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: when the total money in an economy the money supply increases too rapidly the quality of the money the currency value often decreases
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: economists generally think that this money supply increase monetary inflation causes the goods services price increase price inflation over a longer period
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: they disagree on causes over a shorter period
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the demand pull inflation theory can be said simply as too much money chasing too few goods in other words if the will of buying goods is growing faster than amount of goods that have been made then prices will go up
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: this most likely happens in economies that are growing fast
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: whenever a product is bought or sold beyond its real price for its worth then inflation of money occurs
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the cost push inflation theory says that when the cost of making goods which are paid by the company go up they have to make prices higher to make profit out of selling that product
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: the higher costs of making goods can include things like workers wages taxes to be paid to the government or bigger costs of getting raw materials from other countries
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: however austrian school economists think this is wrong because if people have to pay higher prices this just means they have less to spend on other things
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: almost everyone thinks excessive inflation is bad
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: inflation affects different people in different ways
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: it also depends on whether inflation is expected or not
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: if the inflation rate is equal to what most people are expecting anticipated inflation then we can adjust and the cost is not as high
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: for example banks can change their interest rates and workers can negotiate contracts that include automatic wage hikes as the price level goes up
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: problems arise when there is unanticipated inflation
lines.name: Simple English

lines.value: * inflation citizendium
lines.name: Simple English
